content: Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include aliens identified in the terrorist screening database, with an exception for those lawfully admitted for permanent residence. SEC. 2 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to prevent the deportation of lawful permanent residents identified in the terrorist screening database. SEC. 3 provides waivers for inadmissibility for these individuals. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for individual case-by-case basis consideration for granting nonimmigrant visas in the national security interests of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with unanimous concurrence from other key officials, may grant a waiver for an alien to be admitted into the United States temporarily as a nonimmigrant if it is in the national security interests of the country. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. (a) Asylum and withholding of removal provisions in the Immigration and Nationality Act are amended to include new categories of inadmissibility and deportability. (b) Cancellation of removal for certain permanent residents is also modified to specify inadmissibility exceptions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new categories of inadmissibility and deportability for residents. Cancellation of removal for certain nonpermanent residents is also modified to specify exceptions for inadmissibility. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new categories of inadmissibility and deportability for residents, with exceptions for certain cases. Voluntary departure for aliens is restricted based on their inadmissibility or deportability status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new categories of inadmissibility and deportability for residents, with exceptions for certain cases. Adjustment of status and registry provisions are also updated to reflect these changes. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new categories of inadmissibility and deportability for residents, with exceptions for certain cases. Adjustment of status and registry provisions are updated to reflect these changes, including revisions to the regulations under the Convention Against Torture. The Secretary of Homeland Security will revise regulations implementing the Convention Against Torture to exclude certain aliens from protection and make them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. The Secretary of Homeland Security will revise regulations to exclude certain aliens from protection and make them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. The revised regulations will allow for reopening and readjudication of past determinations, applying to acts and conditions constituting grounds of ineligibility regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine the inadmissibility or deportability of such aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to issue removal orders to such aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act grants the Secretary of Homeland Security the power to issue removal orders to aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. Aliens described in the act may be subject to removal if they have not been granted a waiver and meet certain criteria. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to issue removal orders to certain aliens who have not been granted a waiver and meet specific criteria outlined in the act. Proceedings for these aliens must follow expedited procedures as prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to certain aliens under expedited proceedings, ensuring the alien's rights to notice, representation by counsel, opportunity to inspect evidence, and rebut charges. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to certain aliens under expedited proceedings, ensuring the alien's rights to notice, representation by counsel, opportunity to inspect evidence, rebut charges, verify the individual's identity, maintain a record for judicial review, and prevent adjudication by the same person issuing charges. Judicial review must be allowed within 14 days of the order issuance unless waived by the alien. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to certain aliens under expedited proceedings, ensuring the alien's rights to notice, representation by counsel, opportunity to inspect evidence, rebut charges, verify the individual's identity, maintain a record for judicial review, and prevent adjudication by the same person issuing charges. No alien adjudicated inadmissible or deportable shall be eligible for any relief from removal that the Secretary of Homeland Security may grant in the Secretary's discretion. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. This Act and its amendments will be effective upon enactment and will apply to all aliens in the terrorist screening database after that date.
